Manual.name: TDD: Mastering Aria Automation Deployment Placement and YAML Templates on VCF 5.2.1

LocaleContent.title: You are ready....is your lab?
LocaleContent.content: The lab console will indicate when your lab has finished all the startup routines and is ready for you to start. If you see anything other than "Ready", please wait for the status to update.  If after 5 minutes your lab has not changed to "Ready", please ask for assistance.

ContentNode.title: How to Copy from manual and Paste into Console

LocaleContent.title: How to Copy from manual and Paste into Console
LocaleContent.content:
1. Use your mouse to select the text you wish to copy
  2. When you release the mouse button to complete your selection, a context menu shows up - Click Copy
    NOTE: Right click on selected text DOES NOT bring up a copy option and CTRL+C/CMD+C does not work
  3. Place your cursor/prompt at the location you wish to paste inside the console
  4. Click the Clipboard icon to bring up the "Send text to console" window
  1. Paste the contents of your clipboard into the window using Right-Click -> Paste, or your OS Keyboard combination of either CTRL+V or CMD+V
  2. Click the "SEND" button to send the text to the console
  3. Click the "CANCEL" button when you are done sending text to the console. This will close the popup window
  1. Confirm that your pasted text is at the desired location

LocaleContent.title: Lab Guidance
LocaleContent.content:
Welcome! To start somewhere other than the beginning, use the Table of Contents in the upper right-hand corner of the Lab Manual or click on one of the modules below.

From here you can:

  1. Click to advance to the next page and continue with the next lab module
  2. Open the TABLE OF CONTENTS to jump to any module or lesson in this lab manual
  3. Exit your lab and come back and resume it again in the future
  4. Send Ctrl+Alt+Del to the console
  5. Send Text into (Paste) the console
  6. Enter Full-Screen
  7. Detach the Lab Manual
  8. Collapse the Lab Manual

LocaleContent.title: Default chapter
LocaleContent.content: • Lab Guidance

LocaleContent.title: Cloud Services Access
LocaleContent.content:
You are now ready to dive into the labs!  READY, SET, GO!

Aria Automation Cloud Services

1. Go to the VMware vRealize Automation Portal at https://aria-auto.vcf.sddc.lab/ to access Aria Automation  

2. Click on the GO TO LOGIN PAGE button

Select the system.domain  domain and click Next

Sign in with username configadmin / VMware123!

You should see the following services

vSphere vCenter Access

Verify that you can sign in to vSphere vCenter. Open another tab in your browser and go to https://vcenter-mgmt.vcf.sddc.lab to access. 

Login with your administrator@vsphere.local / VMware123!VMware123!

You should see the following:

LocaleContent.title: Cloud Services Access
LocaleContent.content: • Cloud Services Access

LocaleContent.title: 1. Add Folders for Resource Pools
LocaleContent.content:
Let's begin by opening a browser window to https://vcenter-mgmt.vcf.sddc.lab/ and logging in.

Enter the following to log in:

Username: administrator@vsphere.local

Password:  VMware123!VMware123!

1. Under the VM and folders tab , under vcenter-mgmt.vcf.sdd.lab, click on the cluster - mgmt-datacenter-01-01 and right click

2. Click on New Folder > New VM and Template Folder

3. Enter Livefire-Prod

4. Click on OK to save

5. Repeat for Livefire-Dev and Livefire-Test

LocaleContent.title: 1.1 Create Resource Pools
LocaleContent.content:
1. On the Server Tab

2. Under vcenter-mgmt.vcf.sddc.lab > mgmt-datatcenter-01, click on the cluster - mgmt-cluster-01 and right click

2. Click on New Resource Pool

 

21.  Enter the following:

Name:  Name:  Livefire-Test-RP

CPU

Shares:  Normal

Reservation:  12000 MHz CPU Shares MHz

Reservation Type: Check Expandable

Limit: Unlimited MHz

Memory

Shares:  Normal

Reservation:  49152 MB

Limit: Unlimited MB

Reservation Type: Check Expandable

 

Confirm that you see the newly created resource pool on the left side of the vSphere Client window

Repeat steps and create an additional resource group for Dev each using the following:

Name:  Livefire-Dev-RP

CPU

Shares:  Normal

Reservation:  12000 MHz CPU Shares MHz

Reservation Type: Check Expandable

Limit: Unlimited MHz

Memory

Shares:  Normal

Reservation:  49152 MB

Limit: Unlimited MB

Reservation Type: Check Expandable

Repeat steps and create an additional resource group for Prod each using the following:

Name:  Livefire-Prod-RP

CPU

Shares:  Normal

Reservation:  12000 MHz CPU Shares MHz

Reservation Type: Check Expandable

Limit: Unlimited MHz

Memory

Shares:  Normal

Reservation:  49152 MB

Limit: Unlimited MB

Reservation Type: Check Expandable

ContentNode.title: 2. Setting Up the Cloud Assembly Configuration

LocaleContent.title: 2. Setting Up the Cloud Assembly Configuration
LocaleContent.content:
Let's begin by opening a browser window to https://aria-auto.vcf.sddc.lab/ and logging in.

  1. Start by opening Assembler under My Services.
  2. Enter the following to log in:
  3. Username: configadmin
  4. Password:  VMware123!

LocaleContent.title: 3. Setup Cloud Accounts
LocaleContent.content:
1. Click on Infrastructure
  2. Click on Cloud Accounts
  3. Click ADD CLOUD ACCOUNT

4. Click on vCenter Server

5. Enter the following:

  1. Name:  Livefire-Labs-MGMT
  2. IP address / FQDN:  vcenter-mgmt.vcf.sddc.lab
  3. Username:  administrator@vsphere.local
  4. Password: VMware123!VMware123!

6. Click VALIDATE

7. Proceed to the Configuration section

8. Once validated, more configuration options will appear

9. Under the Configuration section, enter the following:

    a. Allow Provisioning to these datacenters: Check the mgmt-datacenter-01

    b.  Do NOT select the "Create a cloud zone for the selected datacenters"...we will do this manually

10. Click ADD add the bottom to create the new Cloud Account Configuration

LocaleContent.title: 3.1 Integrate NSX-T into Cloud Services
LocaleContent.content:
1. Click on Infrastructure
  2. Click on Cloud Accounts
  3. Click ADD CLOUD ACCOUNT

4. Click on NSX-T Manager

5. Enter the following:

  1. Name:  Livefire-Labs-NSX-MGMT
  2. IP address / FQDN: nsx-mgmt.vcf.sddc.lab
  3. Username:  admin
  4. Password: VMware123!VMware123!
  5. Manager type: Local
  6. NSX mode: Policy
  7. Click on Validate

7. Add the associated Cloud account by clicking ADD

8. Select your Livefire-Labs-MGMT cloud account.

9. Click ADD

Click ADD to save the new cloud account

LocaleContent.title: 4. Add Tags to Resource Pools
LocaleContent.content:
While in Assembler under My Services, go back to the Infrastructure tab

  1. Click on Compute
  2. Open the mgmt-cluster-01/Livefire-Prod-RP resource pool
  3. Add the following tag - Environment:Production
  4. Repeat for the mgmt-cluster-01/Livefire-Test-RP and add the Environment:Test tag
  5. Repeat for the mgmt-cluster-01/Livefire-Dev-RP and add the Environment:Development tag

NOTE: These are regular metadata tags and are primarily used to provide additional context or information about compute resources. They help with organizing, categorizing, and managing resources but do not enforce any operational constraints or define specific capabilities.

LocaleContent.title: 3. Set Up Your Project
LocaleContent.content:
1. Click on Infrastructure
  2. Click on Administration
  3. Click on Projects
  4. Click on NEW 

5. Enter a project name: Livefire-Labs

6. Click on the Provisioning tab

7. Click on the ADD ZONE option

8. Click on Cloud Zone

9. Select your Livefire Cloud Zone - Livefire-Prod

10. Enter 1 for Provisioning Priority

11. Accept the remaining defaults

10. Click ADD

Repeat for the Livefire-Test (Provisioning priority - 0) and Livefire Dev (Provisioning priority - 1)

You should see the following:

11. Click on the Users tab

12. Click on the ADD USERS option

13. Search for configadmin

14. Click on Administrator for the role

15. Click on ADD

16. Click on CREATE

LocaleContent.title: 5. Create New Cloud Zones
LocaleContent.content:
While in Assembler under My Services.

  1. Go to Infrastructure
  2. Click on Cloud Zones
  3. If there any existing Cloud Zones, please delete before continuing
  4. Click on NEW

4. Enter the following:

    Account/ region: Livefire-Labs-MGMT / mgmt-datacenter-01

    Name: Livefire-Prod

    Placement Policy: DEFAULT

    Folder: Livefire-Prod

5. Add the following Capability Tags:

    DeploymentType:Holodeck    

    env:vsphere  

6. On the Compute Tab, add the previously created Resource Pools

 - Select Manually select compute from the dropdown

  - Select ADD to see the available Compute

7. Select the mgmt-cluster-01 / Livefire-Prod-RP that was created in the previous steps

8. Click on ADD  

9. Click on CREATE to save the new resource

Repeat for both both Dev and Test Cloud Zones using the following:

 

Account/ region: Livefire-Labs-MGMT / mgmt-datacenter-01

    Name: Livefire-Test

    Placement Policy: DEFAULT

    Folder: Livefire-Test

    Compute: mgmt-cluster-01 / Livefire-Test-RP

    Capability Tags: DeploymentType:Holodeck     env:vsphere  

 

Account/ region: Livefire-Labs-MGMT / mgmt-datacenter-01

    Name: Livefire-Dev

    Placement Policy: DEFAULT

    Folder: Livefire-Dev

    Compute: mgmt-cluster-01 / Livefire-Dev-RP

    Capability Tags: DeploymentType:Holodeck     env:vsphere

LocaleContent.title: 6. Add Flavor Mapping
LocaleContent.content:
While in Assembler:

  1. Go to Infrastructure
  2. Click on Flavor Mappings
  3. Click on NEW

Enter the following:

1. Flavor name: Large

2. Account / Region: Livefire-Labs-MGMT / mgmt-datacenter-01

Value:

3. 4 (CPUs)

4. 8 (Memory)

5. GB

6. 1 (Core per socket)

7. Click on CREATE to save

Repeat the same for medium and small flavor mappings using the following:

1. Flavor name: Medium

2. Account / Region: Livefire-Labs-MGMT / mgmt-datacenter-01

Value:

3. 2 (CPUs)

4. 4 (Memory)

5. GB

6. 1 (Cores per socket)

 

1. Flavor name: Small

2. Account / Region: Livefire-Labs-MGMT / mgmt-datacenter-01

Value:

3. 1 (CPUs)

4. 2 (Memory)

5. GB

6. 1 (Cores per socket)

LocaleContent.title: 7. Add Image Mapping
LocaleContent.content:
While in Assembler:

  1. Go to Infrastructure
  2. Click on Image Mappings
  3. Click on NEW

Enter the following:

1.  Image name: ubuntu

2.  Configuration:

       Account / Region: Livefire-Labs-MGMT / mgmt-datacenter-01

      Image: Holo-Template

3. Click on CREATE to save

LocaleContent.title: 8. Add Network Profiles
LocaleContent.content:
A network profile in Aria Automation is a set of predefined network settings and configurations that can be applied to VMs or other resources. These profiles simplify the process of network configuration by allowing administrators to define and reuse network settings across multiple resources.

While in Assembler:

  1. Go to Infrastructure
  2. Click on Network Profiles
  3. Click on NEW

Enter the following:

1.  Account / Region:  Livefire-Labs-MGMT / mgmt-datacenter-01

2.  Name: OC-Auto-Seg (Dev)

3.  Capability tags:

   DeploymentType:Holodeck

   Environment:Development

4. Click on the Networks Tab

5. Click on ADD NETWORK

6. Select OC-DB-Auto-Seg

7. Click ADD to save

8. Click CREATE to create the network profile

Repeat for the OC-Auto-Seg(Test) network profile and enter the following:

1.  Account / Region:  Livefire-Labs-MGMT / mgmt-datacenter-01

2.  Name: OC-Auto-Seg(Test)

3.  Capability tags:

   DeploymentType:Holodeck

   Environment:Test

4. Add the OC-Web-Auto-Seg network on the Networks tab

5. Click on CREATE to save

Repeat again for the OC-AUTO-Seg(Prod) network profile and enter the following:

1.  Account / Region:  Livefire-Labs-MGMT / mgmt-datacenter-01

2.  Name: OC-Auto-Seg(Prod)

3.  Capability tags:

   DeploymentType:Holodeck

   Environment:Production

   network:dmz

4. Add the xregion-seg01 network on the Networks tab

5. Click on CREATE to save

LocaleContent.title: Add Storage Profiles
LocaleContent.content:
In Aria Automation, a storage profile is a set of predefined settings and configurations for managing storage resources. It simplifies and standardizes how storage is allocated and configured for virtual machines (VMs) and other resources.

Also note that we are associating each Storage Profile to its corresponding Resource Pool to support the partitioned environment.

While in Assembler:

  1. Go to Infrastructure
  2. Click on Storage Profiles
  3. Click on NEW

Enter the following:

1.  Account / Region:  Livefire-Labs-MGMT / mgmt-datacenter-01

2.  Name: Livefire-standard

3. Disk type - Standard disk

4. Compute - mgmt-cluster-01 / Livefire-Dev-RP

Accept defaults for all remaining entries excluding Priority and Capability tags

5. Priority: 1

6. Check the Preferred storage for this region box

7. Capability tags:

    cas.storage.profile:standard

8. Click on CREATE to save

Repeat steps to add the Livefire-PCI storage profile using the following:

1.  Account / Region:  Livefire-Labs-MGMT / mgmt-datacenter-01

2.  Name: Livefire-PCI

3. Disk type: Standard disk

4. Compute:

    mgmt-cluster-01 / Livefire-Test-RP

5. Storage policy:

    Datastore default

Accept defaults for Provisioning type, Shares, Limit IOPs and Disk mode

6. Priority:

    Priority 0 

7. Check the Supports Encryption box

8. Capability tags:

    cas.storage.profile:pci

9. Click on CREATE to save

Repeat steps to add the Livefire-PCI-2 storage profile using the following:

1.  Account / Region:  Livefire-Labs-MGMT / mgmt-datacenter-01

2.  Name: Livefire-PCI-2

3. Disk type: Standard disk

4. Compute:

    mgmt-cluster-01 / Livefire-Prod-RP

5. Storage policy:

    Datastore default

Accept defaults for Provisioning type, Shares, Limit IOPs and Disk mode

6. Priority:

    Priority 1 

7. Check the Supports Encryption box

8. Capability tags:

    cas.storage.profile:pci

9. Click on CREATE to save

Your Storage Profile should look like the following:

LocaleContent.title: Configure Cloud Services
LocaleContent.content:
In this lab, you'll be creating an partitioned environment using Cloud Zones within Cloud Assembler. 

NOTE: As you work through the lab exercises, please pay close attention to the capability and constraint tags used in the configuration settings. These tags play a crucial role in defining the parameters and limitations of the system you are working with.

Capability Tags: These indicate the features and functions that the system can support. Ensure that you are aware of these capabilities as they will guide you in setting up the configuration correctly and making full use of the system’s features.

Constraint Tags: These specify the limitations and restrictions within which the system operates. Understanding these constraints is essential to avoid errors and to ensure that your configurations are within acceptable limits.

Always check for these tags and settings where available to ensure proper setup and functionality. This attention to detail will help you avoid potential issues and make your lab experience more productive.

LocaleContent.title: Importing the Blueprints
LocaleContent.content:
1. In Cloud Assembly navigate to the Design tab

2. Select NEW FROM from Upload

3. Name your blueprint Livefire-Placement.

4. Select Livefire-Labs for the project

5. Select the template from the  C:\Users\Administrator\Document\Livefire_Labs directory

6. Click on UPLOAD

7. Repeat for the Livefire-Placement-2 template and name the file  Livefire-Placement-2

LocaleContent.title: 01. Setting up the Blueprints
LocaleContent.content: In this chapter we will Clone (or Import) a base Blueprint that we will use as a skeleton and build upon. We will also start configuring the Blueprint inputs to match our company needs.

LocaleContent.title: Getting Started with Cloud Assembler
LocaleContent.content:
• Configure Cloud Services
  • 01. Setting up the Blueprints

LocaleContent.title: 00. Lab Introduction
LocaleContent.content:
In this lab we are going to show how placement decisions are being made by Aria Cloud Assembly, and how we can affect these decisions via Constraint Tags on different resource objects.  

We are going to place a storage constraint for our disks and see how this affects provisioning.  Next we are going to do the same for our networks.

ContentNode.title: 01. Adding a PCI Resource Constraint Tag

LocaleContent.title: Fixing the Failing Deployment
LocaleContent.content:
Open the Design , then Templates tab in Assembler.

Clone the Livefire-Placement template and name it Livefire-Placement-Test.

Select Livefire-Labs for the Project and Current Draft for the version.

Open the new template and examine the blueprint. Note that we only have size (flavor) and environment inputs.

Also note that the our machine resources must comply with PCI regulations so we've put a constraint on the disk: 'cas.storage.profile:pci'

Deploy the blueprint to the Production environment and select small  as the flavor. Note that you will receive an error as shown below.

Why is the deployment failing? 

Examine the deployment request details from the Provisioning diagram for more info.

How would you fix the broken deployment? 

Do not delete the deployment at the end of the lab.

Solution: Fixing the Failing Deployment

Examine the deployment request details from the Provisioning diagram for more info.

Examine the blueprint. Especially the constraints on the Cloud Machine resource.

According to the constraint tags we are looking for a Storage profile that contains the following capability tags:

                 - tag: 'cas.storage.profile:standard'

                - tag: 'cas.storage.profile:pci'

 

Examine the Storage profiles. You will notice that there is no storage profile that has all of capability constraints.

 

To fix this we are going to make the standard constraint a soft constraint. We want to keep pci as we want to comply with PCI standards.

To fix this, change the standard constraint on the cloud machine resource to:

         - tag: 'cas.storage.profile:standard:soft'

Deploy the blueprint again to the Production environment and select small  as the flavor  This time deployment should be successful.

 

Examine the deployment request details.  Examine the storage provisioning request details.  Where was the deployment placed?

Do not delete the deployment at the end of the lab.

LocaleContent.title: 01. Adding a PCI Resource Constraint Tag
LocaleContent.content: In this lab we are going to add some additional constraints regarding PCI on the database disks.  We are going to examine how these affect the deployment engine decisions for resource placement.

LocaleContent.title: Understanding the Placement Decision
LocaleContent.content:
Examine again the deployment request details from the previous lab. Examine the resource request details.

Your deployment ended up in the Livefire-Prod-RP.  

Now, revisit the template and note that there is also a env:vsphere hard constraint tag in the template which is not listed as a capability constraint on the Cloud Zone Computes.  And...the deployment didn't fail but why?

Why didn't the deployment fail when neither of the Resources Pools contained the hard constraint tag?

HINT 1

Cloud Assembly uses something called tag inheritance.

Solution: Understanding the Placement Decisions

Navigate to Infrastructure > Cloud Zones, and open the Livefire-Prod Cloud Zone.

This Cloud Zone  has Capability tags that include the following  'DeploymentType:Holodeck', 'env:vsphere'. The 'Environment:Production' tag can be seen under the Compute tab as it is associated with the Livefire-Prod-RP.  This means that all resources listed under the corresponding compute will inherit the capability tags listed in the Summary tab for the Cloud Zone and making the env:vsphere' constraint an applicable tag.

So in summary, if you apply a tag to a cloud account, it can automatically be applied to the compute resources (like virtual machines) within that account.

LocaleContent.title: 02. Understanding the Placement Decision (PCI)
LocaleContent.content: In this lab, we are going to try to figure out how the placement engine made the decision to place the deployment where it did.

ContentNode.title: 03. Adding a DMZ Network Constraint Tag

LocaleContent.title: Deployment Placement with Inputs
LocaleContent.content: Since there's no OOB method of connecting the network and cloud machine resources, let's create one. It's actually already configured in the Livefire-Placement template using inputs. By passing the constraints received from the Cloud Machine input parameters to the network settings we are able to assign the same constraints to both.

LocaleContent.title: Adding DMZ Network Capability Constraint
LocaleContent.content:
1. Clone the Livefire-Placement-2 template.

2. Name the new template Livefire-Placement-DMZ

3. Create a new deployment and name it Pre-DMZ...accept the defaults.

4. Make note of which Cloud Zone the deployment was placed in.  Why do think the deployment was placed in Livefire-Test this time when both Livefire-Test and Livefire-Prod have the PCI constraint tag?

The answer is in the Project configuration. The deployment engine placed the deployment in the Livefire-Test Cloud Zone because it has higher priority in the Project configuration.

1. Now update the Livefire-Placement-2 template with the DMZ constraint tag

2. Add the following Constraint Tag for the Cloud Network:

      constraints:

         -tag:  network:dmz

Deploy using the defaults inputs.

Examine the deployment request details from the Requests tab for more info.

But before you do, where do you think the deployment was placed?

OK, now check...were you correct?

Why did the deployment engine decide to place the deployment in (your guess)?

DO NOT delete the deployment at the end of the lab.

HINT 1

The fill in the blank answer is Test, but why did it get placed there?

Solution: Adding DMZ Network Capability Constraint

From the previous PCI lab, we can see that the PCI constraint tag is applied to both the Livefire-PCI-2 and Livefire-PCI storage profiles making both the Livefire-Prod-RP and Livefire-Test-RP viable options.  And if you recall our inputs chose the Production environment for the placement.

However, with the DMZ template, we are allowing the deployment engine to choose the environment placement.

And as noted above, in the first deployment the deployment engine chose the Livefire-Test Cloud Zone as it has higher priority in the Project.

After adding the DMZ constraint to the network, did this change have any effect on the Cloud Zone deployment placement?  

NOPE...although the deployment was assigned to the Production network the VM was still deployed to the Livefire-Test-RP.  This is because tags on the network do not determine where the cloud machine is placed as there is no correlation between the network tags and the cloud tags.  We can however control placement if we use inputs as configured in the previous template.

 

DO NOT delete the deployment at the end of the lab.

LocaleContent.title: 03. Adding a DMZ Network Constraint Tag
LocaleContent.content:
In this lab, we are going to put a DMZ constraint to our blueprint for the networks. We are going to examine how these affect the deployment engine decisions for resource placement.

To test, create a deployment using the original Livefire-Placement template.

1. Deploy the template and select the environment of your choice

2. Now review the placement...you'll find that deployment is now assigned to the same Network Profile environment and Cloud Zone environment.

This completes the labs and in summary, ARIA automation tags are essential for optimizing deployment decisions. In this lab, you’ve learned how to place resources according to priority, environmental constraints, and other key factors. These tags help organize and automate tasks, ensuring deployments are efficient and aligned with our goals. By using ARIA automation constraint and capability tags, we streamline processes, reduce errors, and enhance overall performance, making our deployment strategy more effective and adaptable.

LocaleContent.title: Understanding Placement Decisions
LocaleContent.content:
• 00. Lab Introduction
  • 01. Adding a PCI Resource Constraint Tag
  • 02. Understanding the Placement Decision (PCI)
  • 03. Adding a DMZ Network Constraint Tag

LocaleContent.title: Lab Introduction
LocaleContent.content:
In this lab we are going to build a Aria Automation Assembler template. The template will not be advanced in terms of the number objects it contains, rather it will be advanced in terms of the YAML code used to achieve the desired result.  We will show how we can build advanced input presentations, build and reference YAML custom properties, create objects on demand, template versioning and many other things.

Once we have finished creating the template, we will release it to Service Broker as catalog items.

LocaleContent.title: Setting up the Blueprint
LocaleContent.content:
In this section we will Import a base template that we will use as a skeleton and build upon. We will also start configuring the template resources to match our needs.

Importing the Template
  1. In Assembler navigate to the Design tab.
  2. Select Templates menu option.
  3. Select  NEW FROM.
  4. From dropdown select Upload.
  1. Name your template YAML-Explore. 
  2. Add it to the existing Livefire-Labs project.
  3. SELECT FILE "YAML-Explore.yaml" from your Documents\Livefire_Labs folder and click Open.
  4. Click Upload.
Renaming resource

Open the template YAML-Explore. Under resources section of yaml code.

  1. Click on line 12 and rename Cloud_Network_1 to app-net.
  2. Rename Cloud_Machine_1 to web-tier in line 16.
  3. Also since network resource is referenced in VM resource, rename Cloud_Network_1 to app-net in line 22.

Alternatively, we can also rename a resource by

  1. Selecting a resource in canvas.
  2. Then click on properties.
  1. Under properties tab, click on the resource name and update new name. Rename Cloud_Network_1 to app-net and rename Cloud_Machine_1 to web-tier.

Note:- If we change the name of resource within properties tab, all reference to that resource are also updated.

LocaleContent.title: Template versioning
LocaleContent.content:
Versioning is an age old tradition in almost all forms of tech. We can also create versions for our cloud templates. There are multiple reasons to create versions of a template.

  • For creating multiple catalog items using versions within the same template.
  • As a restore point.
  • As a reference point for creating a new template.

We will use versions as a glimpse/snapshot of our template evolution from the very basic to an advanced template.

Creating Template version
  1. For creating a version click on Version.
  1. Update Version as 1.
  2. Under Description update simple template for deploying a VM.
  3. Then click Create.
Reviewing all versions in a template
  1. To get details of all Version, click  VERSION HISTORY.
  1. All versions are listed in order with Version number and description.
  2. Select the arrow icon to revert to canvas.

ContentNode.title: Deploying template and updating existing deployment

LocaleContent.title: Deploying template and updating existing deployment
LocaleContent.content:
In this section we are going to deploy our template, explore the deployed VM, modify our template by adding a property and resource flag to web-tier resource and update an existing deployment.

A common consensus among the community is that updating a deployment is commonly reserved for creation/testing of template and not in production.

Deploying the template

Lets now deploy our base template.

  1. Click Deploy.
  2. Update the Deployment name as multi-stage-deployment.
  3. Then click Next.

Under Deployment inputs section update,

  1. Image as ubuntu.
  2. VM Size as Small.
  3. Click Deploy.
Exploring the deployment section

Deployment view is divided int 3 sections, lets explore each section in detail:

  1. In this section of the window you will find information about the deployment as a whole. Common information available here includes:
    • Deployment name
    • Requestor name
    • Link to template
    • Deployment status
    • Actions that affect entire deployment (PowerOff VM, Update, Delete etc)
  2. In this section we can see various Topology views , complete history of deployment including all updates and user events which shows the inputs passed with deployment/update.
  3. Under this section we can interact with (initiate/cancel day2 actions) and view details of an individual resource and progress of an action within the deployment.
Reviewing deployment in vCenter

Login to vCenter https://vcenter-mgmt.vcf.sddclab/ui

  1. Under inventory view select VMs and Folders tab.
  2. Expand Livefire-Dev folder.
  3. Explore the details of newly created VM.

Even though we have not provided any instructions (constraints) in our template. Deployment will always happen in Livefire-Dev vmfolder and Livefire-Dev-RP resource pool as the Storage Profile associated with the Livefire-Dev-RP pool is set as the Default.

In earlier releases of Aria Automation, the priority for of the Cloud Zone was the determining factor in this case, resulting in the VM having been placed in the Livefire-Test folder and Livefire-Test-RP..

Adding property in a resource

Lets add a property to web-tier resource.

  1. Go back to the template and add a new line below line number 18 and
  2. type co, a list of all matching properties are available to chose from.
  3. Select count property and update value as 2.
count: 2

Observe the changes to web-app resource in the canvas. With the update in code, canvas gets automatically updated and vice-versa.

Any changes made to the template will automatically be saved.

Updating existing deployment
  1. Click on Deploy.
  2. Select Update an existing deployment as Deployment Type.
  3. Select multi-stage-deployment and
  4. Select Next.
  1. Leave deployment inputs as it is and click Next.
  1. Under Plan you will find existing VM will be deleted and new VMs based on the count property inputs be added. Click Cancel.

Now if we were to click Deploy, existing VM would be deleted first and new VMs will be created only after existing VM is deleted. In our case we want new VM to be deployed first and only then exiting VM to be deleted. For that to happen we will add a resource flag and set the value as true.

createBeforeDelete: true

You can find the list of all available resource flags here.

Now update the existing deployment, steps are explained earlier.

Within the deployment, select History section and examine event sequence. First web-tier[1] creation started and after that web-tier VM was deleted.

New template version

Add new version for the template with

  1. Version as 2
  2. description as resource flag and property added to VM resource.
  3. Click Create.

LocaleContent.title: Adding expressions
LocaleContent.content:
What is an expression?

When we provide input to any property within a resource which is not value (string/integer/boolean) then its an expression.

Example:-

  • ${input.count}                                                            <= simple expression
  • ${"env:" + to_lower(input.environment)}.     <=expression with a function
  • '${input.size == "small" ? 1 : 2}'                           <=expression with a condition

Complete list of expressions can be found here.

Adding expressions

We are now going to add Volume resource to our template.

  1. Drag and drop Volume resource from Cloud Agnostic section into canvas.
  2. Then connect the resource to web-tier VM resource.
  3. And finally rename the Volume resource to app-storage.

Our aim is to create 1 virtual disk per VM. As per current senario, since 2 VMs will be deployed 2 virtual disks need to be created. Disk 1 to be connected to VM1 and disk2 to be connected to VM2.

Hint:- Use properties tab to rename Volume resource, it will rename all bindings within the code too.

In our template we have now introduced a problem. When we try to deploy this template, aria automation will try to create 1 virtual disk and connect this disk to all VMs part of web-tier, since vCenter will not allow that, our deployment will fail.

Now how to fix the problem we introduced.

  • To create same number of disks and VMs we will use count property. We will use count property for web-tier and app-storage resource.
  • To allocate 1 volume to each VM we will use resource flag allocatePerInstance.  We will use this property for web-tier and app-storage resource.
  • To attach correct disk to VM we will use expressions map_to_object and slice expressions in web-tier resource.

allocatePerInstance resource flag will be applied to both VM and Volume resource.

map_to_object expression creates an array of key value pair, in our case key is property source and value is volume id.

slice expression takes list as input and carves out a section of the list based on the index provided as inputs

count.index property here is a reference to number for current resource.

How slice works.

slice(list, start_index, end_index) -> with slice we can get a subset of a list, subset will include items from start_index till end_index but excluding end_index.

Example

list = [1,2,3,4,5,6]

slice(list, 2,4) == [3,4]

Modified code should look same as below.

Since we are no longer recreating the web-tier resource, comment out line 19 by placing a # before createBeforeDelete.

formatVersion: 1
inputs:
  image:
    type: string
    title: Image
    description: template/image to be used for deployment
  flavour:
    type: string
    title: VM Size
    description: Compute resource allocation for the VM
resources:
  app-net:
    type: Cloud.Network
    properties:
      networkType: existing
  web-tier:
    type: Cloud.Machine
    allocatePerInstance: true
    #createBeforeDelete: true
    properties:
      count: 2
      image: ${input.image}
      flavor: ${input.flavour}
      networks:
        - network: ${resource.app-net.id}
      attachedDisks: ${map_to_object(slice(resource["app-storage"][*].id, count.index, count.index+1 ), "source")}
  app-storage:
    type: Cloud.Volume
    allocatePerInstance: true
    properties:
      capacityGb: 1
      count: 2

If we were to expand the code and understand how it will look for each web-tier resource.

In our case,  for web-tier[0], the first element in the resource array, should expands to:

web-tier[0]:      
	type: Cloud.vSphere.Machine      
	properties:        
		image: ubuntu        
		flavor: small        
		attachedDisks:            
			- source: ${resource.app-storage[0].id}

For web-app[1], the second element in the resource array, should expands to:

web-tier[1]:      
	type: Cloud.vSphere.Machine      
	properties:        
		image: ubuntu        
		flavor: small        
		attachedDisks:            
			- source: ${resource.app-storage[1].id}

Lets test the template against our existing deployment. Click Deploy and update our existing deployment multi-stage-deployment, leave deployment inputs as it is and click Deploy. Under Plan we can see 2 Volumes added and 2 VMs being updated.

After successful deployment, create a new version with Version as 3 and Description as 'add disk to each VM in web-tier'.

Lets increase the complexity a bit

Now lets add another disk to our web-tier and explore how the code changes.

  • Drag and drop another Volume in canvas.
  • Change the size of volume to 2, add count property and set value to 2.
  • Rename the Cloud_Volume_1 to temp-storage.

Now to add second disk to web-tier resource, modify attachedDisks section.

attachedDisks: ${map_to_object(slice(resource.app-storage[*].id, count.index, count.index+1), "source") + map_to_object(slice(resource.temp-storage[*].id, count.index, count.index+1), "source")}

Here we are using map_to_object expression twice to get both disks added and we are using + (Arithmetic operator) to combine the expressions. Arithmetic operator in our case is merging 2 arrays into 1.

Hence the resulting code for web-tier[0] will look like.

web-tier[0]:      
	type: Cloud.vSphere.Machine      
	properties:        
		image: ubuntu        
		flavor: small        
		attachedDisks:            
			- source: ${resource.app-storage[0].id}
			- source: ${resource.temp-storage[0].id}

Our complete code should look like.

formatVersion: 1
inputs:
  image:
    type: string
    title: Image
    description: template/image to be used for deployment
  flavour:
    type: string
    title: VM Size
    description: Compute resource allocation for the VM
resources:
  app-net:
    type: Cloud.Network
    properties:
      networkType: existing
  temp-storage:
    type: Cloud.Volume
    properties:
      capacityGb: 2
      count: 2
  web-tier:
    type: Cloud.Machine
    allocatePerInstance: true
    #createBeforeDelete: true
    properties:
      count: 2
      image: ${input.image}
      flavor: ${input.flavour}
      networks:
        - network: ${resource.app-net.id}
      attachedDisks: ${map_to_object(slice(resource.app-storage[*].id, count.index, count.index+1), "source") + map_to_object(slice(resource.temp-storage[*].id, count.index, count.index+1), "source")}
  app-storage:
    type: Cloud.Volume
    allocatePerInstance: true
    properties:
      capacityGb: 1
      count: 2

Deploy the template by updating existing deployment. Observe Plan section, adding 2 volumes and updating 2 VMs.

After completing the deployment, create another version. Version as 4 and description as 'Adding multiple disks to web-tier resource'.

LocaleContent.title: Adding inputs to template
LocaleContent.content:
In current template we already have 2 inputs defined. Our task in this section is to add more inputs and make inputs more user-friendly

  1. Select Inputs section,
  2. then click on image input.
  3. In new window select scroll bar
  4. Then expand More Options.
  1. Under Enum add 3 values,
  • ubuntu
  • CentOS
  • PhotonOS
  1. Select default value as ubuntu and click Save.

Similarly under flavour input add small, medium and large as input options, with small as default.

Create new input with

  1. Name = count
  2. display name = VM Count
  3. type = Integer
  4. Expand More Options.
  1. Minimum = 1
  2. Maximum = 4
  3. Click Create.

We will be using count input to set the number of VMs. Set count property value in web-tier resource to ${input.count}

count: ${input.count}

Now your input section of the code should look like.

inputs:
  image:
    type: string
    title: Image
    description: template/image to be used for deployment
    default: ubuntu
    enum:
      - ubuntu
      - RedHat
      - CentOS
  flavour:
    type: string
    title: VM Size
    description: Compute resource allocation for the VM
    default: small
    enum:
      - small
      - medium
      - large
  count:
    type: integer
    title: VM Count
    minimum: 1
    maximum: 4

ContentNode.title: Lets add inputs with key value pair.

LocaleContent.title: Lets add inputs with key value pair.
LocaleContent.content:
Add new input with below values.

  • Name: location
  • Display Name: Location
  • Type: String
  • For values add Enumerated List types as Key and values pair with default value being 'Adding multiple disks to web-tier resource.
Key Value
vSphere env:vsphere
AWS env:aws
Azure env:azure

At this point input section of code should look like.

inputs:
  image:
    type: string
    title: Image
    description: template/image to be used for deployment
    enum:
      - ubuntu
      - CentOS
      - PhotonOS
  flavour:
    type: string
    title: VM Size
    description: Compute resource allocation for the VM
    default: small
    enum:
      - small
      - medium
      - large
  count:
    type: integer
    title: VM Count
    minimum: 1
    maximum: 4
  location:
    type: string
    title: Location
    default: env:vsphere
    oneOf:
      - title: vSphere
        const: env:vsphere
      - title: AWS
        const: env:aws
      - title: Azure
        const: env:azure

We will not use this input as of now.

Add another property with key value pair input options

  • Name: env
  • Display Name: Environment
  • Type: String
  • For values add Enumerated List types as key and value pair with default value being Environment:Production.
Key Value
Prod Environment:Production
Test Environment:Test
Dev Environment:Development

We will also be not using this input now.

LocaleContent.title: Adding object type input property
LocaleContent.content:
We will now add array type input to get user input on number of additional disks to be added to web-tier resource. Input will include name of the disk and size of disk, there is will be limit on how many disks to be added and maximum and minimum size of each disk.

Create new input with below details and then click Create.

  • Name: disk_config
  • Display Name: Add Additional disk
  • Type: Array
  • Min Items = 0 and Max Items = 3

Return to code section and add below code to disk_config input. Copy the code below and replace the disk_config input section.

  disk_config:
    type: array
    title: Add Additional Disks
    minItems: 0
    maxItems: 3
    items:
      type: object
      properties:
        disk_name:
          type: string
          title: Name of disk
          default: ''
        disk_size:
          type: number
          title: Size of disk in GB
          default: 1
          minimum: 1
          maximum: 10

So what we are doing here, within the disk_config array input we are creating items of type object (which is another input type). An object can have multiple properties. We are creating disk_name and disk_size as inputs.

At this point if we click on test to check template inputs, it should look like the image below.

ContentNode.title: Using inputs to set resource values

LocaleContent.title: Using inputs to set resource values
LocaleContent.content:
Since we are getting input for all volumes from our object array input, temp-storage resource is no longer needed. Delete the resource, click vertical ellipsis > Delete.

Now lets update app-storage resource to create all disks from input and update web-tier resource to add correct disks to each web-tier resource. Our code now will look like this.

resources:
  app-net:
    type: Cloud.Network
    properties:
      networkType: existing
  web-tier:
    type: Cloud.Machine
    allocatePerInstance: true
    #createBeforeDelete: true
    properties:
      count: ${input.count}
      image: ${input.image}
      flavor: ${input.flavour}
      networks:
        - network: ${resource.app-net.id}
      attachedDisks: ${map_to_object(slice(resource['app-storage'][*]['id'], length(input.disk_config) * count.index, length(input.disk_config)*(count.index + 1) ),"source")}
  app-storage:
    type: Cloud.Volume
    allocatePerInstance: true
    properties:
      name: ${input['disk_config'][count.index % length(input.disk_config)]['disk_name']}
      capacityGb: ${input['disk_config'][count.index % length(input.disk_config)]['disk_size']}
      count: ${length(input.disk_config) * input.count}

Lets break down the complexity for app-storage resource.

  • count property for the volume is straight forward enough, number of disks provided as input multiplied by the number of VMs.
  • count.index is the position of the current volume in the resource array. As we iterate through the array, this will be 0 and then 1 and so on.
  • To get capacityGB and name we used a mathematical formula. Turns out if we divide 0 by any number remainder is always 0, similarly if we divide 1 by any number remainder is always 1 and so on. Using this formula we can get the index value from array of disks.

Let break down complexity for attached disks in web-tier resource.

  • count.index is the position of the current VM in the resource array. As we iterate through the array, this will be 0 and then 1 and so on.
  • map_to_object will create a key value pair, in our case it will create a list of key value pair with source being the key and volume.id being the value.
  • slice expression will help us get the correct volumeID.
  • resource['app-storage'][*]['id'] is an array of volume IDs.
  • length(input.disk_config) * count.index, this will equate to 0 for 1st web-app resource, n (if n is number of disks) for 2nd resource and n+n for 3rd resource and so on.
  • length(input.disk_config)*(count.index + 1), this will equate to n for 1st web-app resource, n+n+1 for 2nd resource and so on

We can understand this better with an example.

Lets consider, we are creating 2 VMs and 6 disks(3 per VM). Now we will explore how the calculations will work in that case.

1st-disk = 1

2nd-disk = 2

3rd-disk = 3

Lets start with disks. All disks are created in sequence as per input. So sequence will be 1st-disk => 2nd-disk => 3-disk. And since we are going to create 2 VMs, this sequence will repeat.

  • number of disks we need is 6 disks (3 disk in a VM * 2 VMs) => aka => length(input.disk_config)*input.count
  • Now to get capacityGB we use % (Modulus). Count.index represents the current resource.
    • On first iteration, count.index= 0, length(input.disk_config)= 6. Therefore 0 mod 6 = 0 which means ${input.disk_config[0].disk_size} is used.
    • On second iteration, count.index= 1, length(input.disk_config)= 6. Therefore 1 mod 6 = 1 which means ${input.disk_config[1].disk_size} is used.
    • On  third iteration, count.index= 2, length(input.disk_config)= 6. Therefore 2 mod 6 = 2 which means ${input.disk_config[2].disk_size} is used.
    • On  fourth iteration, count.index= 3, length(input.disk_config)= 6. Therefore 3 mod 6 = 3 which means ${input.disk_config[3].disk_size} is used.
    • On  fifth iteration, count.index= 4, length(input.disk_config)= 6. Therefore 4 mod 6 = 4 which means ${input.disk_config[4].disk_size} is used.
    • On  sixth iteration, count.index= 5, length(input.disk_config)= 6. Therefore 5 mod 6 = 5 which means ${input.disk_config[5].disk_size} is used.
  • Exact same approach is used to get disk name.

 

Now lets look into how we map correct disk IDs with each VM.

  • resource['app-storage'][*] => it is the list of all Cloud.Volume(disk) resources, in our case list of 6 Cloud.Volume resources.
  • resource['app-storage'][*]['id'] => it is the list of ids for all Cloud.Volume resources,  in our case list of 6 Cloud.Volume resource ids.
  • length(input.disk_config) => total number of Cloud.Volume resources, for us this number is 6.
  • count.index => represents the current resource. Since we are talking in reference to our Cloud.Machine resource, the value can be 0 or 1.
  • slice(resource['app-storage'][*]['id'], length(input.disk_config) * count.index, length(input.diskConfig) * (count.index +1)) => This will iterate through each Cloud.Machine resource and get a subset of Cloud.Volume resource
    • On first iteration for web-tier[0], will return a list containing elements between index (3 x 0 =) 0 and index (3 x 1 =) 3, i.e.resource.app-storage[0].id, resource.app-storage[1].id, and resource.app-storage[2].id.
    • On second iteration for web-tier[1], will return a list containing elements between index (3 x 1 =) 3 and index (3 x 2 =) 6, i.e.resource.app-storage[3].id, resource.app-storage[4].id, and resource.app-storage[5].id.
  • map_to_object will create a key value pair, with key being source and value will be the each element of slice method mentioned above.

Lets visualize the expanded property view for our web-tier[0] resource

web-tier[0]:
  type: Cloud.Machine
  properties:
    image: ${input.image}
    flavor: ${input.flavour}
    networks:
      - network: ${resource.app-net.id}
    attachedDisks:
      - source: ${resource['app-storage'][0]['id']}
      - source: ${resource['app-storage'][1]['id']}
      - source: ${resource['app-storage'][3]['id']}

LocaleContent.title: Input based resource allocation
LocaleContent.content:
User inputs, they are added to create flexibility and customizations to any template. A simple example would be to create a template that can deploy a resource to private (vCenter) or public (VMC, AWS, Azure or Google) cloud.

In the lab, we are going to explore all available input types from simple types (string, numbers and boolean) to more complex input types (array, object)

LocaleContent.title: Adding vCenter to Orchestrator inventory
LocaleContent.content:
We can leverage objects and workflows from Orchestrator that interact with vCenter. In order to take advantage of this capability, we'll need to add a vCenter instances to the Orchestrator Inventory.

Let's get started...

Add vCenter Server Instance

In Orchestrator, you will need to add a vCenter Server Instance so that you can run workflows over the objects in the vSphere infrastructure.  This will allow Orchestrator to create a snapshot of the SQL VM when it is deployed.

  1. From the Aria Automation Console, Select the 9 dots in the top right hand corner
  2. Right Click Orchestrator
  3. Click Open in new tab, then click into the Orchestrator tab in the browser
  1. From the left side, select Workflows
  2. 1. Filter for Add a vCenter Server Instance
  3. 2. Click on run to configure the workflow
  1. Under the Set the vCenter Server instance properties tab enter the information as per the table below
Configuration Option Value
IP or Hostname of the vCenter Server vcenter-mgmt.vcf.sddc.lab
HTTPS port of the vCenter Server 443
Location of the SDK /sdk
Do you Want to Ignore Certificate Warnings Yes (Tick the box)
  1. Click Set the connection properties tab and configure as per the table below
Configuration Option Value
Do you want to create a session per user No (Uncheck the box)
Username that the Automation Orchestrator will use administrator@vsphere.local
Password that the Automation Orchestrator will use VMware123!VMware123!

Click the Additional Endpoints tab and check the setting in the table below Note: They should be auto-filled

Configuration Option Value
URL of PBM endpoint https://vcenter-mgmt.vcf.sddc.lab:443/pbm
URL of SMS endpoint https://vcenter-mgmt.vcf.sddc.lab:443/sms/sdk
  1. Click on RUN
  1. Monitor until the status is a completed
  2. Click Close

We can validate that the instance is now configured by viewing the Inventory

  1. From the left side, select Inventory under Administration
  2. Expand the vSphere vCenter Server, your vCenter and then Datacenter

You should see your management datacenter

LocaleContent.title: Importing Orchestrator package
LocaleContent.content:
In this section we are going to import a package in our Aria Automation Orchestrator. A package is a portable way to share actions and workflows to different orchestrator instances.

Importing Orchestrator Package

We need to import a package in orchestrator. This package contains all required workflows

In Orchestrator, you will need to add a vCenter Server Instance so that you can run workflows over the objects in the vSphere infrastructure.  This will allow Orchestrator to create a snapshot when the SQL VM when it is deployed.

  1. From the Aria Automation Console, Select the 9 dots in the top right hand corner
  2. Right Click Orchestrator
  3. Click Open in new tab, then click into the Orchestrator tab in the browser
  1. Click on Packages.
  2. Then select IMPORT.
  1. Within explorer window, select com.company.livefire.package under path C:\Users\Administrator\Document\Livefire_labs.
  2. Click Open.
  1. Click TRUST, then click IMPORT to import the package in Aria Automation Orchestrator.

LocaleContent.title: Adding day 2 activity
LocaleContent.content:
After we create a deployment based on a cloud template, we can run different lifecycle (day 2) actions on both the deployment and its resources. Aria Automation Assembler includes many Day 2 actions out of the box, but we might want to create others to meet different requirements. We can achieve this by creating custom Resource Actions.

Resource Actions can be based either on Aria Automation Orchestrator workflows or Action Based Extensibility (ABX) actions and can be applied to either embedded or custom resources.

In this lesson we will create a custom Resource Action using Aria Automation Orchestrator to move a deployed vSphere Machine resource to a different vSphere folder.

In this lab, we will quickly cover the basics of using Aria Automation Orchestrator and Aria Automation to perform extensibility tasks.

In this lesson we have successfully created a custom Resource Action which calls an Aria Automation Orchestrator Workflow to complete a Day 2 operational task on a virtual machine resource.  In this example we moved a virtual machine to a new folder in VMware vCenter but the possibilities are only limited by your imagination.

Create a custom Resource Action

While logged to Aria Automation and click on the Assembler Service

  1. Click on the Design Tab
  2. Select Resource Actions
  3. Select + NEW button under Resource Actions to begin creating our new Resource Action

We will begin to enter the required information to create the Resource Action:

  1. Enter remove_additional_volumes for the Name of our Resource Action
  2. Enter Delete additional volumes, this will be the Display name for our Resource Action
  3. Toggle the Activate slider so that we enable the Resource Action
  4. Click +ADD to add the Resource Type that this action is associated with 
  5. As this Resource action will be for a vSphere Machine we will need to specify this for our Resource Type: Cloud.vSphere.Machine

Now that we have selected our Resource Type we now need to select the workflow that we would like to run against it:

1. Scroll Down to view the rest of the form, then Click +ADD in Action/Workflow to add a workflow

NOTE : Resource Actions can be associated with Aria Automation Orchestrator workflows or ABX Actions, however only a single workflow or action can be selected for each Resource Action. We also cannot combine a workflow and action together within a single Resource Action.

Through the out of the box vSphere integration, Aria Automation Orchestrator comes with an existing workflow to move virtual machines to a folder. This means we do not need to create our own:

  1. In the search field enter 'Livefire delete'.
  2. Select the Livefire delete additional drives workflow from the search results
  3. Click ADD to add it to our Resource Action 

The Property Bindings section on the request form is now populated detailing the Property Bindings.

We use the Property Binding feature to ensure the corresponding workflow or action receives the correct inputs (either manually or automatically) to be able to execute successfully.

There are three Property Binding types:

  • In request which basically means the value will be set at request time via an interactive dialog
  • Direct which basically allows us to define the property (schema) of the resource to pass as a binding
  • With binding action allows us to choose a binding Aria Automation Orchestrator action to run to bind to the Data Type

As there is one Property Binding listed, the workflow requires single input:

  • vm which is of Aria Automation Orchestrator data type, VC:VirtualMachine

As this Resource Action is related to the Cloud.vSphere.Machine Resource Type, and we need to translate that to the VC:VirtualMachine type, we are going to update the Property Binding to use a binding action to automatically provide the right resource information for the resource the action is being completed on:

  1. Locate "virtual_machine" in the Action input column
  2. Click in request in the Binding column

We now need to select the appropriate binding action to complete the mapping of our Virtual Machine types:

  1. In Binding select the with binding action radio button
  2. The findVcVmByVcAndVmUuidaction is automatically selected
  3. Click SAVE

NOTE: We observed that the findVcVmByVcAndVmUuid action was automatically selected and configured. This is due to the fact that when running the embedded version of Aria Automation Orchestrator, the integration with Aria Automation Assembler is automatically configured.

1. Click EDIT REQUEST PARAMETERS

Click SAVE to save the Resource Action before we edit the Request Parameters form

Even though we have configured a binding action, the field for the Virtual Machine object will still be displayed on the form at request time.  We can customize the request form for the Resource Action, so that the Virtual Machine field is not displayed:

  1. Select the virtual_machine field on the Form
  2. Set Visibility to No
  3. Click SAVE to save the changes
Test Your Custom Resource Action

Now let's now open a new tab in browser and open your vSphere vCenter client.https://vcenter-mgmt.vcf.sddc.lab  

Login with your administrator@vsphere.local / VMware123!VMware123!

  1. Select the VM's and templates view
  2. Examine the hard disks connected to each VM.
  3. Each VM should have more than 1 hard disks connected.
  4. Return to the Assembler tab
  1. Select Resources to find your multi-stage-deployment deployment from the previous lab
  2. Expand the multi-stage-deployment deployment
  3. Click the vertical ellipsis next to one of the virtual machines to view the list of Resource Actions
  4. Click on the scroll bar to the right of the actions list to scroll down
  5. Notice that our Custom Resource Action appears in the list, Select Delete additional volumes.

Notice that our request form does not have an input for virtual machine name, this is because we stated visibility = no when customizing the form for that field:

  1. Click  Next and then click SUBMIT
  1. The action will now run and the deployment screen will automatically update with a Status field showing the progress of the action.
  2. Wait while the action runs, the Status field will automatically update with a green banner and a value of Delete additional volumes Successful.
  3. Run the Day 2 action on all deployed VMs within the deployment.

Let's now check that the workflow associated with the action successfully deleted additional hard disk:

  1. Return to the vSphere tab
  2. Notice that our Virtual Machine has on 1 hard disk connected.

Before we complete this lesson, we are going to view the Aria Automation Orchestrator workflow run within the Aria Automation Orchestrator interface.

  1. Return to the Aria Automation console
  2. Select the 9 dots in the top right hand corner
  3. Select Orchestrator
  1. Click Dashboard in the left pane
  2. Ensure that the USAGE panel is selected
  3. Note in the Recent Workflow Runs section you will see that the workflow Livefire delete additional drives was completed

LocaleContent.title: Testing template with multiple inputs
LocaleContent.content:
If you are curious, why we ran the Day 2 activity and deleted all additional hard disks from the VMs. With all the changes in the template, it is not compatible with existing deployment. If we were to update our deployment without Day 2 action it would fail with error in allocating new hard disks.

Now lets test our template against existing deployment.

Click Deploy > Update existing deployment > select multi-stage-deployment > Next. Under Deployment Inputs set VM Count to 3 and add 3 additional disks.  After giving much thought we have carefully selected these names and size inputs.

Name of disk Size of disk in GB
First_disk 1
Second_disk 2
Third_disk 3

Deployment inputs should look like the image below.

Click Next and observe under Plan section

  • 9 Volumes to be created.
  • 1 VM to be created and 2 VMs to be updated.

Click Deploy to update the deployment.

Create new template version after successful deployment.

Version: 5

Description: Inputs of type string, integer, array and object used

LocaleContent.title: Using custom resource in template
LocaleContent.content:
Go back to the template,

  1. from the list of resources search for custom resource. Custom resource with name VM Folder is available for consumption
  1. Drag and drop the custom resource in the canvas. Rename the Custom_VMFolder_1 to web-app-folder
  2. Create new input to get name of the VM folder
    • Name = vmfolder
    • Display Name = VM Folder
    • Type = String

Our custom resource has some requirements of its own. To create a vmfolder, 2 inputs are required, vmfolder name and parent folder under which in the new vmfolder needs to be created. We have addressed vmfolder name by creating an input. Lets now address the parent folder input.

  1. To create parent folder input:
    • Go back to our VM Folder custom resource
    • Select properties tab
    • Code section of custom resource VM Folder is already selected. Copy the content from line 19 to 29
  1. Paste the copied content in the template, below vmfolder input.
  1. We now need to bind inputs to the custom resource. Bind name property to input vmfolder and parentFolder to the input parentFolder.
  web-app-folder:
    type: Custom.VMFolder
    properties:
      name: ${input.vmfolder}
      parentFolder: ${input.parentFolder}

Click Test to get a glimpse of how template input looks like.

NOTE: For parent folder, you'll need to type something in order for the search to start showing up. Try: vm

LocaleContent.title: Creating custom resource
LocaleContent.content:
By default there is a big list of resources available in template designer to just drag and drop within the canvas. But not all resource types are present, we can create a custom resource type in Aria Automation to use within the template.

To create custom template go to Design tab > Custom Resources > New.

Create new custom resource with

  1. Name as VM Folder
  2. Resource Type as Custom.VMFolder
  3. Click on the slider to activate the custom resource
  4. Since we want the custom resource to be only available to our project. Click on slider to disable Scope
  5. Select Livefire-Labs as Project
  6. Custom resource can be based on Orchestrator workflow or ABX actions. We are using Orchestrator workflow
  7. Under Lifecycle Actions we will add Create and Delete action. Click + ADD to link a Orchestrator workflow
  1. Select workflow by name Create virtual machine folder
  2. Click ADD
  1. Similarly, for Destroy action click +ADD and select workflow Delete virtual machine folder
  2. For Additional actions, click +ADD
  1. Within the Add Action tab update below inputs
    1. Workflow = Rename virtual machine folder
    2. Name = rename-vm-folder
    3. Menu label = Rename virtual machine folder
  1. click ADD
  1. Finally click Create.

Inputs required to create a custom resource depends on the inputs of the underlying workflow/ABX action used. To explore the inputs and outputs related to the resources, open custom resource > click on properties section. Schema of the resource is available in code as well as Form(GUI). We will utilize the code section in our template.

LocaleContent.title: Creating a subscription
LocaleContent.content:
By using a Automation Orchestrator integration, or extensibility actions with Automation Assembler, you can create subscriptions to extend your applications.

Extensibility subscriptions allow you to extend your applications by triggering workflows or actions at specific life-cycle events. You can also apply filters to your subscriptions to set Boolean conditions for the specified event. For example, the event and workflow or action only triggers if the Boolean expression is 'true'. This is helpful for scenarios where you want to control when events, actions, or workflows are triggered.

In this lesson we will create an Extensibility Subscription that will trigger an Aria Automation Orchestrator workflow to automatically move VM to vmfolder when a VM deployment is completed.

Getting the Cloud Template ID

You now need to grab the Cloud Template Id by locating it in the URL.

  1. While your new template YAML-Explore is open, grab and copy the ending text field from the URL at the top of the screen.  Be sure to grab the text that begins after the 2F as shown below
  2. Click the search icon, type notepad and then open it
  3. Paste the ID into Notepad, and then minimise it. Note:You will need this Cloud Template Id when configuring your subscription in the later steps
Add a New Subscription

We'll switch back over the Assembler now to continue configuring the integration between Assembler and Orchestrator

Click the Assembler.

  1. Click Extensibility
  2. Click Subscriptions from the men u on the left
  3. Click  + NEW to begin creating our new Subscription
  1. In the name field enter the name of our Subscription as move_vm_to_folder.
  2. In the description filed enter the text Move VM to VMFolder.
  3. Click on the + ADD button in the Event Topic box to add a new event topic.

The event topic determines the timing within the request lifecycle when our Workflow will be executed.. As we are moving our VMs to vmfolder, we want to be able to call our Workflow after the virtual machine is created in vCenter, so that our VMs are moved at last. We will use the Compute post provision topic in this example. This topic runs after resources have been confirmed in vCenter to allow the virtual machine build to complete.

  1. In the window that pops up for Event Topics you can use the filter field in the top right to search for the event topic you want to use.  Enter the text Compute post provision
  2. Aria Automation filters the results based on your search criteria. Select Compute post provision from the list
  3. Click SELECT to confirm your choice
  1. Click on the Filter events in topic slider to enable:
  2. Copy the code mentioned below. 
event.data.blueprintId == 'blueprintId'
  1. Replace 'blueprintId' with Cloud Template Id you copied to notepad earlier.
  2. Click +ADD next to Action/Workflow
  1. Click the Runnable Type dropdown box and select WORKFLOW
  2. In the filter on the right, type Livefire-Move-VM-To-Folder
  3. Click the radio button next to the workflow
  4. Click SELECT

Back in the Subscription view, you will set our Subscription to blocking so that our Aria Automation request won't continue until it is completed successfully

  1. Click on the Block execution of events in topic slider to enable it, you may need to scroll down the screen to see this option.
  2. Click SAVE to save the subscription

You have now configured your subscription to use the custom property referenced in your Cloud Template which will call your workflow to move web-tier VM resource to vmfolder when provisioned.

ContentNode.title: Creating custom property for resources in template

LocaleContent.title: Creating custom property for resources in template
LocaleContent.content:
Custom properties are resource properties we create within the YAML code. During deployment, Aria Automation ignores these properties. These properties are mostly used for:

  • Our own reference
  • Custom Day2 actions
  • Triggering secondary automation via subscriptions

In our case, we are using a custom property via subscription for moving our VM resource to the VMFolder created during template deployment

In past few sections we created custom resource and subscription, to bind all these together we will create a custom property which will be used by orchestrator workflow (Livefire-Move-VM-To-Folder).

Feel free to explore the workflow within the orchestrator.

We have 1 more challenge that we need to overcome, our VMFolder needs to be created before web-tier VM resource. If not, then our orchestrator workflow will fail.

For that to happen we are going to use dependsOn resource flag. Keep an eye on the canvas, as you add this flag a representation of binding will be visible.

dependsOn: 
  web-app-folder

Now lets add the custom property in web-tier resource. We are naming the property folderIDProp.

Name of the property tells us about what will be the value of this property.

  • folderID => this property will hold the ID of the vmfolder where VMs are to be moved.
  • Prop => this is our way of signifying that this is a custom property.

Now lets add the property to our web-tier resource.

folderIDProp: ${resource.web-app-folder.newFolder.id}

How did we arrive at this value for our property. Lets go back to our custom resource and explore the property section.

Go to Design > Custom Resources > VM Folder > Properties > Form

In the form newFolder object is listed as the output property. That means newFolder variable holds all the details of the vmfolder(created during the deployment) and we need id property from it.

With these changes code for our web-tier resource should look like:

web-tier:
  type: Cloud.Machine
  dependsOn: 
    web-app-folder
  allocatePerInstance: true
  #createBeforeDelete: true
  properties:
    folderIDProp: ${resource.web-app-folder.newFolder.id}
    count: ${input.count}
    image: ${input.image}
    flavor: ${input.flavour}
    networks:
      - network: ${resource.app-net.id}
    attachedDisks: ${map_to_object(slice(resource['app-storage'][*]['id'], length(input.disk_config) * count.index, length(input.disk_config)*(count.index + 1) ),"source")}

Lets now create new template version:

Version: 6

Description: Add custom resource, custom property and subscription to the template

LocaleContent.title: Pop Quiz
LocaleContent.content:
In this section we are going to force our deployment to the cloud of our choosing and in a specific environment within that cloud. Use the knowledge attained in earlier labs to achieve this in our current template.

Till now the cloud zone used by our deployment was not under our control. Aria automation was deploying resources on the priority of cloud zones within the project. Your mission should you choose to accept is to force the deployment to cloud and environment of your choosing.

I would strongly suggest not to directly jump to solution and come up with your own. Your solution could very well be different from ours and thats perfectly fine.

Hint

To now force the deployment to correct cloud zone we need to add constraints to our network and VM resources. We already have created inputs for location and environment, use them to create constraint tags.

Solution

To force VMs to be created in vCenter :) we will use location as a constraint tag

constraints: 
  - tag: ${input.location}

To force network and VMs in a specific environment within a location we will use environment as constraint in network

constraints: 
  - tag: ${input.env}

Now the combined code for web-tier and app-net should look like.

app-net:
  type: Cloud.Network
  properties:
    networkType: existing
    constraints: 
      - tag: ${input.env}
web-tier:
  type: Cloud.Machine
  dependsOn: 
    web-app-folder
  allocatePerInstance: true
  #createBeforeDelete: true
  properties:
    folderIDProp: ${resource.web-app-folder.newFolder.id}
    count: ${input.count}
    image: ${input.image}
    flavor: ${input.flavour}
    networks:
      - network: ${resource.app-net.id}
    attachedDisks: ${map_to_object(slice(resource['app-storage'][*]['id'], length(input.disk_config) * count.index, length(input.disk_config)*(count.index + 1) ),"source")}
    constraints: 
      - tag: ${input.location}

LocaleContent.title: Cleanup
LocaleContent.content: Delete all deployments you created at the end of the lab.

LocaleContent.title: Testing the template
LocaleContent.content:
We are at the final stage of our lab and the penultimate task is to put it all together and create a brand new deployment with our template.

It's not a mistake, we have intentionally left this section blank.

We want you to test all aspects of a template.

  • Maximums and minimums (in terms of size and numbers). See if template throws error if you exceed the limit.
  • Use the subscription to force VM to a different vmfolder then default.
  • Modify the template, try something new.
  • Break things and make things.

In the end make sure to delete the deployments as multiple deployment running simultaneously might leed to resource constraints.

ContentNode.title: Bonus- using property Groups as template input
Adding property group in template input.

LocaleContent.title: Adding property group in template input.
LocaleContent.content:
1. Navigate back to the template YAML-Explore
  2. Select inputs section
  3. Open location input
  1. Change type from String to Object
  2. Select object type to Property Groups
  3. Select location property group
  4. Click Save
  1. Under inputs select env input checkbox
  2. Click Delete
  3. Click Delete again to confirm.

ContentNode.title: Referencing property group in YAML code

LocaleContent.title: Referencing property group in YAML code
LocaleContent.content:
Using property group in template is identical to using any input. We start with input namespace and then the input name

input.location

Then reference the exact property within the property group.

${input.location.cloud}

Using this principal lets change the input for both our constraint tags. And now the code for our resources should look like this.

resources:
  app-net:
    type: Cloud.Network
    properties:
      networkType: existing
      constraints:
        - tag: ${input.location.environment}
  web-app-folder:
    type: Custom.VMFolder
    properties:
      name: ${input.vmfolder}
      parentFolder: ${input.parentFolder}
  web-tier:
    type: Cloud.Machine
    dependsOn:
      - web-app-folder
    allocatePerInstance: true
    #createBeforeDelete: true
    properties:
      folderIDProp: ${resource.web-app-folder.newFolder.id}
      count: ${input.count}
      image: ${input.image}
      flavor: ${input.flavour}
      networks:
        - network: ${resource.app-net.id}
      attachedDisks: ${map_to_object(slice(resource['app-storage'][*]['id'], length(input.disk_config) * count.index, length(input.disk_config)*(count.index + 1) ),"source")}
      constraints:
        - tag: ${input.location.cloud}
  app-storage:
    type: Cloud.Volume
    allocatePerInst#ance: true
    properties:
      name: ${input['disk_config'][count.index % length(input.disk_config)]['disk_name']}
      capacityGb: ${input['disk_config'][count.index % length(input.disk_config)]['disk_size']}
      count: ${length(input.disk_config) * input.count}

Order of the resource within the YAML code does not matter, so don't be bothered if sequence of resources in your code is different than one showed above.

LocaleContent.title: Bonus- using property Groups as template input
LocaleContent.content:
When we need to reference the same set of values in multiple templates, instead of creating the input individually in each template we can create a property group and reference them within the template.

Property Groups are of 2 types:

  • Input Property Groups - Added and referenced in a template as an input.
  • Constant Property Groups - These property groups can be directly referenced within the template and are not need to be added as input. We can also create secrets within these property groups.

We are going to use an input property group to reference location and environment as input.

  1. Go to Assembler.
  2. Open Design tab.
  3. Select Property Groups
  4. Click +NEW to create new property group.

Create new property group of type Input Values with,

  1. name: location
  2. Display Name: Location
  3. Project: Livefire-Labs
  4. Click + NEW PROPERTY to add input property.

Create new input property with:

  1. Name: cloud
  2. Display Name: Cloud
  3. Type: String
  4. Default value: env:vsphere
  5. Then click > More Options
  1. Select Enumerated list type as Keys and Values
  2. Enter below key value pairs:
Key Value
vSphere env:vsphere
AWS env:aws
Azure env:azure
  1. Click Create

Create another property with,

Name: environment

Display name: Environment

Type: String

Default value: Environment:Production

Key and value pairs:

Key Value
Prod Environment:Production
Test Environment:Test
Dev Environment:Development
  1. Finally click Create to add the new property group

LocaleContent.title: Cleanup
LocaleContent.content:
Delete all deployments you created at the end of the lab.

GRACIAS AMIGOS !!!

LocaleContent.title: Cleanup (optional)
LocaleContent.content:
It's time spare couple of minutes and cleanup our deployments .

IT REALLY REALLY takes a couple of minutes.

LocaleContent.content:

  • Input based resource allocation
  • Adding vCenter to Orchestrator inventory
  • Importing Orchestrator package
  • Adding day 2 activity
  • Testing template with multiple inputs
  • Creating custom resource
  • Creating a subscription
  • Creating custom property for resources in template

  • Testing the template
  • Bonus- using property Groups as template input
  • Cleanup (optional)
